revision.text:
{{Infobox religious building | building_name=Church of St Mary at Mount Naranco
Iglesia de Santa María del Naranco {{es icon}} | image=Santa maria del naranco-001.jpg | caption= | location= [[Oviedo]], [[Spain]] | geo = {{coord|43|22|44.5|N|5|51|57.5|W|region:ES-O_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | religious_affiliation=[[Roman Catholic]] | rite= | province= [[Asturias]] | district= | consecration_year= 848 | status= Inactive | leadership= | website= [http://www.santamariadelnaranco.blogspot.com Official Website] | architect= | architecture_type= [[Church (building)|Church]] | architecture_style= [[Pre-Romanesque art|Pre-Romanesque]] | heritage_designation = World Heritage Site | facade_direction= O | groundbreaking = | year_completed= | construction_cost= | specifications= yes | capacity= | length={{convert|20|m|ft}} | width={{convert|10|m|ft}} | width_nave= | height_max= | materials= |designation1=WHS |designation1_offname= Monuments of Oviedo and the Kingdom of the Asturias |designation1_date=1985 (9th [[World Heritage Committee|session]]) |designation1_criteria=i, ii, vi |designation1_number=[http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/312 312] |designation1_type=Cultural |designation1_free1name=State Party |designation1_free1value=Spain |designation1_free2name=Region |designation1_free2value=[[List of World Heritage Sites in Europe|Europe and North America]] |designation2=Spanish Property of Cultural Interest |designation2_offname= Santa María del Naranco |designation2_date=24 January 1885 |designation2_number=RI-51-0000047 |designation2_type=Non-movable }} The '''church of St Mary at Mount Naranco''' ({{lang-es|Iglesia de Santa María del Naranco}}; {{lang-ast|Ilesia de Santa María'l Narancu}}) is a [[Roman Catholic]] [[Asturias|Asturian]] [[Pre-Romanesque art|pre-Romanesque]] [[Asturian architecture]] church on the slope of [[Monte Naranco|Mount Naranco]] situated {{convert|3|km}} from [[Oviedo]], northern [[Spain]]. [[Ramiro I of Asturias]] ordered it to be built as a royal palace as part of a larger complex that also incorporated the nearby [[San Miguel de Lillo|church of San Miguel de Lillo]], 100 meters away. It was completed in 842 and consecrated in 848. Its structural features, such as the barrel vault — with transverse ribs corresponding one-to-one with contraforts at the exterior, make it a clear precursor of the Romanesque construction. The exterior decorations, as well as the use of stilted arches mark the intended verticality of the composition. It was declared a [[World Heritage Site]] by [[UNESCO]] in December 1985. It was declared ''[[Bien de Interés Cultural]]'' in 1885.{{citation needed|date=November 2016}} == History == Built as a recreational palace, it is situated on the southern side of [[Monte Naranco|Mount Naranco]] facing the city, and was originally part of a series of royal buildings located in the outskirts. Its character as a civil building changed in the 12th century when it was converted into a church dedicated to [[St. Mary]]. The Palace of Santa María del Naranco, involved a significant stylistic, morphological, constructive and decorative renovation of Pre-Romanesque, supplementing it with new, innovative resources, representing a leap forward with respect to immediately previous periods. On its altar, a Latin inscription provides the date of consecration:''{{lang|la|(...) Per Famulum Tuum Ranimirum. Principe Gloriosum Cum Paterna Regina Coniuge Renovasti Hoc Habitaculum Nimia. Vetustate Consumptvm Et Pro Eis Aedificasti Hanc Haram Benedictionis Gloriosae. Sanctae Mariae In Locum Hunc Summum Exaudi Eos De Caelorum Habitaculo Tuo Et. (...) Die VIIIIo Kalendas Iulias Era Dccclxxxvia}}''.{{cite book|last=De Selgas|first=Fortunato|title=Las Iglesias del Naranco|year=1909|publisher=Boletín de la Sociedad de Excursiones|pages=19–40| url=https://archive.org/stream/boletn1718sociuoft#page/n33/mode/2up|accessdate=5 April 2012| language=Spanish|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090624020601/http://www.archive.org/stream/boletn1718sociuoft|archivedate=2009-06-24}}{{#tag:ref|(...) by means of your servant [[Ramiro I of Asturias|Ramiro]], glorious prince, together with his wife Queen Paterna renewed this building consumed by much antiquity,and by means of them built the east altar for the benediction of glorious Saint Maria in this place (...) The ninth day of the [[calends]] of July 886 (23 June 848).[http://medspains.stanford.edu/demo/themes/art_and_architecture/arch_christian_spain/index.html Architecture in Christian Spain] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080622063016/http://medspains.stanford.edu/demo/themes/art_and_architecture/arch_christian_spain/index.html |date=June 22, 2008 }}|group=note}} This palace's innovations amazed chroniclers, who mention it repeatedly. The [[Crónica Silense]], written around the year 1015, about 300 years after the construction of the palace, said that [[Ramiro I of Asturias]] "built many constructions, two miles away from Oviedo, with sandstone and marble in a vaulted work: (...) He also made (...), a palace without wood, of admirable construction and vaulted below and above,..." The chroniclers marvelled at its proportions and slender shapes, its rich, varied decoration and the introduction of elongated barrel vaults thanks to the transverse arches, allowing support and eliminating wooden ceilings. This solution, timidly advanced in the Camara Santa ({{lang-en|Holy Chamber}}) of the [[Cathedral of San Salvador, Oviedo|Cathedral of San Salvador of Oviedo]], fully matured in Santa María del Naranco. The palace, on a rectangular ground plan, has two floors. The lower level, or [[crypt]], quite low, has a central chamber and another two located on either side. The upper floor is accessed via a double exterior stairway adjoining the facade, leading into an identical layout as the lower floor; a central or noble hall with six blind semicircular arches along the walls, supported by columns built into the wall, and a mirador at each end. These are accessed via three arches, similar to those onto the wall, resting on columns with helicoidal rope moulding, typical of Pre-Romanesque. The barrel vault is made from [[tufa]] stone, and is held up by six transverse arches resting on consoles. Santa María del Naranco represented a step forward from a decorative point of view by enriching the habitual standards and models with elements from painting, gold work and the textile arts. The rich decoration is concentrated in the hall and miradors of the upper floor, where it is especially worth noting the cubic-prismatic capitals (of [[Byzantine architecture|Byzantine]] influence), decorated with reliefs framed by [[Rope|cord]] decoration (from local tradition) in trapezoid and triangular shapes, inside which there are sculpted forms of animals and humans. This kind of motif is repeated on the disks with central medallions located above the blind arches' intersections. The 32 medallions distributed around the building are similar in size and shape, varying the decorative designs and the interior figures (quadrupeds, birds, bunches of grapes, fantastic animals), a style inherited from the Visigoth period, in turn descended from Byzantine tradition. The medallions have decorative bands above them, again framed by rope moulding, inside which four figures are scuipted and arranged symmetrically; the upper two carrying loads on their heads and the lower two representing soldiers on horseback carrying swords. These figures seem to have some kind of symbolic social meaning; the warriors who defend and support the men of prayer, or alternatively, the royal and ecclesiastic orders complementing each other. Santa María del Naranco shows other, equally beautiful and important sculptural elements; for the first time, a [[cross|Greek cross]] appears sculpted as emblem of the Asturian monarchy, at the same time protecting the building from all evil, something which was to become habitual in the popular architecture of towns and villages. Other sculptural elements, such as the capitals of [[Corinthian order|Corinthian]] inspiration on the miradors' triple-arched Windows or the altar stone in the eastern mirador (originally from the neighbouring [[San Miguel de Lillo|Church of San Miguel de Lillo]]), make this palace the most distinctive building in Pre-Romanesque, a singularity highlighted by being the only palace complex that has lasted until the present day with both [[Visigothic]] and [[Carolingian]] court structures. == Building == The church of St Mary at Mount Naranco is unlike any contemporary example we are acquainted with. Practically it is a [[Roman architecture|Roman]] [[tetrastyle]] [[amphiprostyle]] temple,{{cite book|last=Fergusson|first=James |title=A history of architecture in all countries|publisher=John Murray|year=1867|volume=2|pages=123–124|chapter=Book VII: Spanish and Portugal|url=https://books.google.com/?id=uSsDAAAAQAAJ&printsec=toc|isbn=0-548-16204-2}} if such terms can be applied to a Christian edifice. So far as we can understand, the altar was placed originally in one of the porticos, and the worship was consequently probably external. The great difference seems to have been that there was a lateral entrance, and some of the communicants at least must have been accommodated in the interior. The ornamentation of the interior differs from classical models more than the plan. The columns are spirally fluted — a classical form — but the capitals are angular, and made to support arches. On the walls also there are curious medallions fiom which tho vaulting-ribs spring, which seem peculiar to the style, since they are found repeated in the church of [[Santa Cristina de Lena]]. == Gallery == File:Santa Maria del Naranco.jpg|Facade with belvedere File:20060630-Oviedo Santa Maria del Naranco.jpg|Exterior view File:Planta de Santa María del Naranco vectorized.svg|Floor plan of the church File:Santa María del Naranco interior.jpg|Inner view of the lower floor == See also == * [[Asturian art]] == Notes == {{reflist|group=note}} == References == ;Citations {{reflist|2}} ;Bibliography {{refbegin|2}} * {{Catholic|wstitle=Diocese of Oviedo}} * {{cite book|last=Fergusson|first=James |title=A history of architecture in all countries|publisher=John Murray|year=1867|volume=2|pages=123–124|chapter=Book VII: Spanish and Portugal|url=https://books.google.com/?id=uSsDAAAAQAAJ&printsec=toc|isbn=0-548-16204-2}} * {{cite journal|last=Arias Paramo|first=Lorenzo|year=1992|title=Geometría y proporción en la arquitectura prerrománica asturiana|journal=Actas del III Congreso de Arqueología Medieval Española|publisher=Universidad de Oviedo|location=Oviedo|pages=27–37|isbn=978-84-604-1916-7|language=Spanish|url=https://books.google.com/?id=2diqpqpbMeMC&pg=PA27|accessdate=2009-05-31}} {{refend}} == External links == * {{Commons category-inline|Church of Santa María del Naranco}} * [[:es:Santa María del Naranco|Santa María del Naranco]] at the [[Spanish Wikipedia]] * [http://www.santamariadelnaranco.blogspot.com Official page of Santa María del Naranco and San Miguel de Lillo] * [http://sketchup.google.com/3dwarehouse/details?mid=df5b33e5089e59dd72c2127c5c5e6d56 3D model on Google Earth] * [http://www.for91days.com/2010/08/07/santa-maria-del-naranco A photo essay about the Santa María del Naranco] {{Asturian Art|state=uncollapsed}} {{World Heritage Sites in Spain}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Santa Maria del Naranco}} [[Category:848]] [[Category:9th-century churches]] [[Category:World Heritage Sites in Spain]] [[Category:Churches in Asturias|Maria del Naranco]] [[Category:Medieval architecture]] [[Category:Pre-Romanesque architecture in Spain]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Oviedo]] [[Category:Bien de Interés Cultural landmarks in Asturias]] [[Category:848 establishments]] page.title: Self-Portrait with Death Playing the Fiddle

revision.text:
{{Expand German|Selbstbildnis mit fiedelndem Tod|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox artwork|image=Arnold_Boecklin-fiedelnder_Tod.jpg|medium=oil on canvas|year=1872|title=Self-Portrait with Death Playing the Fiddle|height_metric=75|width_metric=61}} '''''Self-Portrait with Death Playing the Fiddle''''' is a painted self-portrait by the Swiss artist [[Arnold Böcklin]]. He first exhibited at the [[Münchner Kunstverein]] in 1872, establishing his reputation in [[Munich]]'s artistic community. It is now in the [[Alte Nationalgalerie]] in Berlin.
{{19C-painting-stub}} [[category:Self-portraits|Bocklin]] [[category:1872 paintings]] [[category:Paintings of the Alte Nationalgalerie]] [[category:Paintings about death]] [[category:Portraits by Swiss artists]] [[Category:Musical instruments in art]] [[Category:Skulls in art]] [[Category:Paintings about painting]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox film festival | name = Superfest International Disability Film Festival | logo = File:Superfest_International_Disability_Film_Festival_Logo.png|alt=Superfest International Disability Film Festival logo | logo_alt = | logo_size = | image = | image_alt = | image_size = | caption = | opening = | closing = | location = [[Magnes Collection of Jewish Art and Life]], [[Contemporary Jewish Museum]] | telephone = | founded = 1970 | founder = | awardsreceived = | awards = | films = | directors = | producers = [[Paul K. Longmore Institute on Disability]], [[LightHouse for the Blind and Visually Impaired]] | writers = | starring = | host = [[Magnes Collection of Jewish Art and Life]], [[Contemporary Jewish Museum]] | number = | date = | language = Primarily [[English language|English]] | website = {{url|superfestfilm.com}} | chronology = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }}
'''Superfest International Disability Film Festival''' is a [[juried (competition)|juried]] [[film festival]] held in the [[San Francisco Bay Area]].<ref name="Festreview"/> Superfest is the longest-running [[disability]] film festival in the world.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://kalw.org/post/your-call-superfest-worlds-longest-running-disability-film-festival#stream/0|title=Your Call: Superfest, the world's longest running disability film festival|last=Aguilar|first=Rose|last2=Flynn|first2=Laura|date=19 October 2016|website=kalw.org/|access-date=27 January 2017}}</ref> In addition to featuring films developed by and starring people with disabilities, Superfest aims to be [[Inclusion (disability rights)|inclusive]].<ref name="Describer">{{cite web|last1=Farrell|first1=Jonathan|title=Op-Ed: Audio Describer donates her voice to help those with disabilities|url=http://www.digitaljournal.com/a-and-e/arts/op-ed-audio-describer-donates-her-voice-to-help-those-with-disabilities/article/404952|website=Digital Journal|accessdate=23 January 2017}}</ref><ref name="Marvelous"/><ref name="Kazakstan"/><ref name="Comedic">{{cite web|last1=Deveras|first1=Reuben|title=Comedic 'Superfest' discusses disability portrayal in film|url=http://goldengatexpress.org/2014/11/04/superfest-2014-disability/|website=Golden Gate Xpress|accessdate=23 January 2017}}</ref> The directors also coach the film makers about accessibility of films to people with disabilities.<ref name="Festreview"/> During the film festival, the organizers provide sign language interpreters and film narrators to allow for the attendees with various disabilities to appreciate the films.<ref name="Celebrates">{{cite web|last1=Ghenis|first1=Alex|title=Superfest International Disability Film Festival Celebrates 30 Years|url=http://www.newmobility.com/2016/09/superfest-celebrates-30-years/|website=New Mobility: Life beyond wheels|accessdate=20 January 2017}}</ref> All of the judges for Superfest are people with disabilities from various community roles, including disability community organizers, disability studies scholars, and film aficionados.<ref name="Marvelous"/><ref name="Kazakstan"/> Superfest closely follows the disability rights slogan: [[Nothing About Us Without Us]].<ref name="Festreview"/>
Stereotypes of disabilities are perpetuated through mainstream media and popular culture.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hayes|first1=Michael T.|last2=Black|first2=Rhonda S.|title=Troubling Signs: Disability, Hollywood Movies and the Construction of a Discourse of Pity|journal=Disability Studies Quarterly|date=2003|volume=23|issue=2|page=114|url=http://dsq-sds.org/article/view/419/585|accessdate=27 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Dahl|first1=Marilyn|title=The Role of the Media in Promoting Images of Disability- Disability as Metaphor: The Evil Crip|journal=Canadian Journal of Communication|date=1993|volume=18|issue=1|url=http://www.cjc-online.ca/index.php/journal/article/viewArticle/718/624%20?iframe=true&width=100%&height=100%|accessdate=27 January 2017}}</ref> The aim of Superfest is to showcase films created by people with disabilities, illustrating real life experiences of disability and how universal the topic of disability can be.<ref name="Marvelous"/><ref name="Kazakstan"/><ref name="Festreview">{{cite web|last1=Toffolo|first1=Matthew|title=Interview with Festival Coordinator Emily Smith Beitiks (Superfest: International Disability Film Festival)|url=https://festivalreviews.org/2016/03/23/interview-with-festival-coordinator-emily-smith-beitiks-superfest-international-disability-film-festival/|website=Festival Reviews|accessdate=24 January 2017}}</ref> Some film submissions are what the disability community refers to as [[inspiration porn]].<ref name="Perceptions"/> These stories are generally regarding people with disabilities completing a great feat, in spite of their disabilities, and never approach the topic of discrimination of people with disabilities or the social standards to which people with disabilities are held.<ref name="Festreview"/> Attendees express they can be authentic at Superfest and speak openly about their experiences.<ref name="Perceptions"/>
Superfest is held over a weekend and is considered more of a cultural event than a film festival.<ref name="Festreview"/> {{TOC limit|2}}
== History == The Superfest International Disability Film Festival began in [[Los Angeles]] in 1970 as a non-profit organization dedicated to promoting films representing the diverse disability community. At that time, Superfest was a small film showcase and not yet considered a film festival.<ref name="Marvelous"/> In 1982, Culture! Disability! Talent! (CDT) took over operations of Superfest. In 1995, CDT decided to move Superfest from Los Angeles to [[Berkeley, California|Berkeley]]. Berkeley is significant to the [[disability rights movement]] and [[independent living movement|independent living]].<ref name="Marvelous"/>
In 1998, Superfest expanded to encompass the San Francisco Bay Area.<ref name="Festreview"/> Annual film festivals were held in Berkeley from 1998 to 2011. In 2009, Superfest held a commemorative two-day program featuring 13 disability films the committee considered classics of disability in film called Superfest Classics.<ref name="Classics">{{cite web|title=Descriptions of Superfest Classics|url=http://culturedisabilitytalent.org/superfest/sf2009.html|website=Internet Archive: Culture! Disability! Talent!|accessdate=30 January 2017|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160325114140/http://culturedisabilitytalent.org/superfest/sf2009.html|archivedate=March 25, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
In 2015, Superfest expanded to a two-day festival and recognized the 25th anniversary of the [[Americans with Disabilities Act]] being signed into legislation.<ref name="Kazakstan">{{cite web|last1=Farrell|first1=Jonathan|title=Op-Ed: Films as far away as Kazakstan will premiere at Superfest|url=http://www.digitaljournal.com/a-and-e/arts/op-ed-films-as-far-away-as-kazakstan-will-premiere-at-superfest/article/447913|website=Digital Journal|accessdate=24 January 2017}}</ref> With the beginnings as a grass-roots organization, Superfest has not been able to have a film festival each year since its founding. The 2016 festival was their 30th film festival.<ref name="Celebrates"/><ref>{{cite web|last1=Smith|first1=Gar|title=Movies in the Margin: The Disability Film Festival, the UN Film Festival, and Films on Fracking|url=http://berkeleydailyplanet.com/issue/2016-10-21/article/45035|website=The Berkeley Daily Planet|accessdate=20 January 2017}}</ref>
== Films shown at Superfest Classics (2009) == {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Film title !! Director !! Producer !! ==The Dissies== In 2013, Superfest presented a special event. This event was to highlight films where disability had been mocked or portrayed in an insensitive manner.<ref name="Dissies">{{cite web|last1=Patterson|first1=James|title=Film event highlights 'disses' of disabled|url=http://www.ebar.com/news/article.php?sec=news&article=69162|website=The Bay Area Reporter|accessdate=27 January 2017}}</ref> These types of films where disability is mocked are referred to as disability snub films.<ref name="Dark">{{cite web|last1=Cipriani|first1=Belo|title=Seeing in the Dark: Film festival celebrates disability|url=http://www.ebar.com/news/article.php?sec=news&article=72012|website=The Bay Area Reporter|accessdate=27 January 2017}}</ref> The "Dissies" mirror the [[Golden Raspberry Awards|Razzies]], where the award given is not an honor at all. Each year, a new "Dissie" is awarded from films nominated by the community. Mock "Dissie" awards are given each year to disability snub films.<ref name="Comedic"/>
{| class="wikitable" style="width=100%" |- ! colspan="2" | The Dissies |- !style="width=50%" | Worst portrayal of a disability by a nondisabled actor !style="width=50%" | So sweet (that they’re not) |- | valign="top"| *'''[[Gene Hackman]] – ''[[Young Frankenstein]]''''' **[[Glenn Close]] – ''[[Fatal Attraction]]'' **[[Richard Pryor]]/[[Gene Wilder]] – ''[[See No Evil, Hear No Evil]]'' | valign="top"| *'''''[[Heidi, Heidi]]''''' **Mary – ''[[The Secret Garden]]'' **Pollyanna – ''[[Pollyanna]]'' |- !style="width=50%" | The Most Amazing Miracle !style="width=50%" | The Most Tragic |- | valign="top"| *'''[[Allan Mann]], ''[[Monkey Shines]]''''' **Forrest Gump, ''[[Forrest Gump]]'' **A Blind Girl, ''[[City Lights]]'' | valign="top"| *'''''[[Million Dollar Baby]]''''' **''[[Scent of a Woman (1992 film)|Scent of a Woman]]'' **''[[Mr. Holland's Opus]]'' **''[[The Other Side of the Mountain]]'' |- !style="width=50%" | The Worst Disabled Villain !style="width=50%" | Crips Gone Wild! |- | valign="top"| *'''Dr. Strangelove – ''[[Dr. Strangelove]]''''' **Pew – ''[[Treasure Island]]'' **Mr. Glass – ''[[Unbreakable (film)|Unbreakable]]'' | valign="top"| *'''Danny – ''[[Blind Dating]]''''' **Carla – ''[[The Other Sister]]'' **Radio – ''[[Radio]]'' |- !style="width=50%" | Hey – only we can laugh at that! |- | valign="top"| *'''''[[The Ringer (2005 film)|The Ringer]]''''' **''[[Tropic Thunder]]'' **''[[Waking Ned Devine]]'' |} Source:<ref name="Dissies2">{{cite web|title=The Dissies – Nominees and "Winners"|url=http://longmoreinstitute.sfsu.edu/pages/dissies-nominees-and-winners|website=Paul K. Moritz–It’d be Cool if She Became an Angel]]'', Director: Simone Grabs, Producer: Eva Radlicki (Germany) *Merit Award – ''Antoine'', Director: Laura Bari, Producers: Laura Bari & Mila Aung-Thwin (Canada) *Merit Award – ''[[Crooked Beauty]]'', Director: Ken Paul Rosenthal, Producer: Angel Vasquez (USA) *Merit Award – ''Departure Lounge'', Director: Louis Neethling, Producers: Louis Neethling & David Horbury (UK) *Merit Award – ''[[Loud, Proud, and Passionate!]]'', Directors: Dana Vion & Sky's the Limit Creative Services, Producers: Susan Sygall & Mobility International U.S.A. (USA) *Merit Award – ''[[Mothersbane]]'' Director & Producer: Jason Jakaitis; U.S. *Pamela K. Walker Award – ''[[Rainman Goes to RocKwiz]]'', Director: Russell Kilbey, Producer: Amy Scully (Australia) *Emerging – ''Hannah'', Director & Producer: Sergio Cruz (UK) Source:<ref name="Awards2"/>
===[[2014 in film|2014]]=== *Best of Festival – ''[[The Interviewer]]'', Directors: Genevieve Clay-Smith and R. Bryan (Australia) *Excellence Award – ''[[Vectors of Autism: A Documentary about Laura Nagle]]'', Director: John Schaffer (USA) *Excellence Award – ''Once Again'', Director: John Spottswood Moore (USA) *Merit Award – ''[[Everything Is Incredible]]'', Director: Tyler Bastian (Honduras) *Pamela K. Walker Award for Innovation in Craft – ''[[The Nature of Pleasure]]'', Director: Thanh Diep (USA) *Advocacy Award – ''[[Restraint and Seclusion: Hear Our Stories]]'', Director: Dan Habib (USA) *Disabled Filmmaker Award – ''[[Krutch]]'', Director: Clark Matthews (USA) Source:<ref name="Awards2"/>
===[[2015 in film|2015]]=== *Best of Festival Feature – ''[[Fixed: The Science/Fiction of Human Enhancement]]'', Director: Regan Brashear (USA) *Best of Festival Short – ''Bastion'', Director: Ray Jacobs (UK) *Advocacy Award – ''[[Do You Dream in Color]]'', Directors: Abby Fuller and Sarah Ivy (USA) *Disabled Filmmaker Award – ''[[Predators of Transylvania]]'', Director: Julia Kolenakova (Slovakia) *Excellence Award – ''To Be Or Not To Be'', Director: Aziz Zairov (Kazakhstan) *Achievement Award – ''[[Sins Invalid: An Unshamed Claim to Beauty]]'', Director: Patty Berne (USA) *P.K. Walker Innovation in Craft Award – ''[[Regione Caecorum (In the Land of the Blind)]]'', Director: Drew Goldsmith (USA) *Artistry Award – ''[[The Gift (of Impermanence)]]'', Director: Alex Ketley (USA) *Disability Comedy Award – ''[[Rent-A-Crip]]'', Directors: Terry Galloway and Diane Wilkins (USA) Source:<ref name="Awards2"/>
== Directors == [[Pamela Walker]] led the film festival efforts from 1998 to 2001, after which, [[Liane Yasumoto]] took over operations.<ref name="Describer"/><ref name="Marvelous"/> [[Catherine Kudlick]], the director of the [[Paul K. Longmore Institute on Disability]] at [[San Francisco State University]], and Bryan Bashin, CEO of LightHouse for the Blind and Visually Impaired, joined together to direct Superfest starting in 2012.<ref name="Describer"/><ref name="Marvelous"/><ref name="Festreview"/>
Since 2012, when the Longmore Institute on Disability and [[LightHouse for the Blind and Visually Impaired]] have directed Superfest, there has been a film festival each year, and the festivals have sold out each time.<ref name="Festreview"/>
== Growth of the festival == Superfest now attracts over 300 attendees during the festival's two-day event.<ref name="Marvelous"/> Film makers from both beginning and established backgrounds showcase their projects at Superfest. Film makers have debuted their films at Superfest and then gone on to receive broader distribution opportunities and further success.<ref name="Marvelous">{{cite web|last1=Farrell|first1=Jonathan|title=Op-Ed: 'Marvelous' Superfest event highlighted disability with 52 films|url=http://www.digitaljournal.com/a-and-e/entertainment/op-ed-marvelous-superfest-event-highlighted-disability-with-52-films/article/413984|website=Digital Journal|accessdate=24 January 2017}}</ref><ref name="Rundown">{{cite web|last1=Erbland|first1=Kate|title=Film Acquisition Rundown: Sony Pictures Classics Grabs ‘The Comedian,’ Breaking Glass Gets ‘Sins Of Our Youth’ And More|url=http://www.indiewire.com/2016/10/film-acquisition-rundown-sony-pictures-classics-the-comedian-breaking-glass-sins-of-our-youth-1201734211/|website=IndieWire|accessdate=27 January 2017}}</ref> The film creators have expressed having Superfest as an opportunity to showcase their work is affirming.<ref name="TerminalDevice">{{cite web|last1=Farrell|first1=Jonathan|title=Op-Ed: 'Man with the hook' in films had to step aside, says filmmaker|url=http://www.digitaljournal.com/life/lifestyle/op-ed-filmmaker-s-polemic-look-at-prosthetic-in-cinema-is-personal/article/476335|website=Digital Journal|accessdate=27 January 2017}}</ref>
In 2016, there were 119 film submissions for Superfest.<ref name="Perceptions">{{cite web|last1=Hauder|first1=Jacqueline|title=Superfest Film Festival challenges media perceptions of people with disabilities|url=http://goldengatexpress.org/2016/10/26/superfest-film-festival-challenges-media-perceptions-of-people-with-disabilities/|website=Golden Gate Press|accessdate=27 January 2017}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * {{official|http://www.superfestfilm.com}}

[[Harold Shapero]] completed the '''Symphony for Classical Orchestra''' in [[B-flat major]] on March 10, 1947, in [[Newton Centre, Massachusetts]]. It is written for an orchestra consisting of [[piccolo]], 2 [[flute]]s, 2 [[oboe]]s, 2 [[clarinet]]s in B-flat, 2 [[bassoon]]s, [[contrabassoon]], 2 [[French horn|horn]]s in F, 2 [[trumpet]]s in C, 2 tenor [[trombone]]s and one bass (silent until the Finale<ref>Along with the piccolo and contrabassoon, pp. 170 — 171 (1992) Pollack. "As its title indicated, the work calls for forces smaller than the modern orchestra," but its exact instrumentation is found only in Beethoven's 5th, right down to the detail that piccolo, contrabassoon and trombones are reserved for the final movement.</ref>), [[timpani]] and strings. Although labelled "Classical," many of the work's features point to Beethoven rather than Haydn or Mozart, such as "the way in which Shapero paces himself, alternating long passages in the tonic and the dominant, with fast, dramatic modulations often reserved for transitions and developments."<ref>p. 173 (1992) Pollack</ref> [[Nicolas Slonimsky]] remarked on how the piece is "premeditatedly cast in the proclamatory key of B-flat major, the natural tonality of the bugle, and ending in a display of tonic major triads."<ref>p. 846 (1971) Slonimsky</ref> But there are modern features as well, with "the work's orchestration, in general, ... distinctively bright and brassy, and undoubtedly derived a fair amount from [[Walter Piston|Piston]] and [[Aaron Copland|Copland]], as well as from the composer's experience as a dance band arranger."<ref>p. 171 (1992) Pollack</ref>
The work is in four movements:
# Adagio {{music|eighth}} = 48, 3/8 — Allegro {{music|half}} = 120 2/2 # Adagietto {{music|eighth}} = 54, [[E-flat major]], 8/8 # Vivace {{music|dottedhalf}} = 132 a due battute or {{music|dottedhalf}} = 138 a quattro battute, [[G major]] — [[E major]] — G major # Allegro con spirito {{music|half}} = 138-144
Some commentators have found hints of the blues in the slow introduction to the first movement.<ref>p. 172 (1992) Pollack. "The form of the introduction itself, with its slow harmonic rhythm and three cadences in the tonic, faintly suggests a "blues" strophe, a suggestion that further contributes to the music's distinctively earthy character."</ref> The ensuing Allegro is.
The Adagietto's theme "is classically balletic, with supple rhythms, graceful turns, sighing fourths, and sweet appoggiaturas and suspensions."<ref>p. 174 (1992) Pollack</ref> The movement consists of "quasi-variations that ... are organized according to the sonata principle."<ref>p. 175 (1992) Pollack</ref>
For the Scherzo, Shapero indicates it could be taken at two measures (battute) or four measures. These instructions naturally suggest the influence of Beethoven's ''Ninth Symphony'', but the scherzo theme itself ... points more directly to the ''Third''; Shapero updates Beethoven's two-note idea ... to include a jazzy flatted third. The movement contains other Beethovenian features: ghostly chromatics, ... a sort of peasant stomping, ... and a generous sense of humor, sometimes quite broad."<ref>pp. 176 — 177 (1992) Pollack</ref>
The Finale is rich in interconnections to the preceding movements, but especially the first movement.<ref>p. 179 (1992) Pollack</ref>
The symphony was given its premiere performance by [[Leonard Bernstein]] conducting the [[Boston Symphony Orchestra]] on January 30, 1948<ref>p. 846 (1971) Slonimsky</ref> and later in Hague.<ref>p. 149, Peyser (1987) Joan. New York ''The Coast-to-Coast Bestseller Bernstein: A Biography'' Ballantine Biography</ref> "Bernstein went on ... to record the whole work with the Columbia Symphony Orchestra, a recording rough in spots, but whose passion and finesse clearly suited the music."<ref>p. 181 (1992) Pollack</ref> By the end of the twentieth century, there was only one other recording of the piece, by [[André Previn]] and the [[Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra]],<ref>p. 767 (2005) Stevenson, "Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra" in Woodstra, Brennan, Schrott (editors) Chris, Gerald, Allen. New York ''All Music Guide to Classical Music: The Definitive Guide to Classical Music'' Hal Leonard Corporation</ref> a fact that has not helped the work's reception.<ref>p. 181 (1992) Pollack</ref> Aaron Copland thought highly of Shapero but did not like his inclination to "hide the brilliance of his own gifts behind the cloak of the great masters."<ref>p. 198 (1999) Pollack</ref> Of Copland's works, Shapero always admired the Short Symphony,<ref>p. 200 (1999) Pollack</ref> even after Copland's popular Symphony No. 3, of which "Shapero criticized, among other things, the first movement's trombone melody."<ref>p. 417 (1999) Pollack</ref>
Much later on in his life, Copland dedicated one of his [[Emily Dickinson]] settings to Shapero.<ref>p. 442 (1999) Pollack</ref> Prior to the Symphony for Classical Orchestra, the composer, still in his twenties, "was producing a series of chamber and orchestral works, each one longer and grander than the last,"<ref>p. 166 (1992) Pollack</ref> but afterwards wrote rather little music for the rest of his life. Fellow composer [[Arthur Victor Berger|Arthur Berger]], who like Shapero was a member of the "Harvard Stravinsky school, and considered the latter to be "arguably the most talented of us all,"<ref>p. 75 (2002) Berger</ref> was puzzled by the way the latter's "composing activity tapered off" after "this illustrious beginning."<ref>p. 76 (2002) Berger</ref>
==References== ;Notes {{reflist|2}}
;Sources * Berger (2002) Arthur. Berkeley ''Reflections of an American Composer'' University of California Press * Pollack (1992) Howard. Metuchen, New Jersey '''Harvard Composers: Walter Piston and His Students, from Elliott Carter to Frederic Rzewski'' The Scarecrow Press, Inc. * Pollack (1999) Howard. Urbana and Chicago ''Copland: The Life and Work of an Uncommon Man'' University of Illinois Press * Slonimsky (1971) Nicolas. 4th Edition. New York ''Music Since 1900'' Charles Scribner's Sons

{{Other uses|Butler (disambiguation)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox film | name = The Butler | image = The Butler poster.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Lee Daniels]] | producer = Pamela Oas Williams
[[Laura Ziskin]]
Lee Daniels
Buddy Patrick
[[Cassian Elwes]] | writer = [[Danny Strong]] | based on = {{based on|"A Butler Well Served by This Election"|[[Wil Haygood]]}} | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Forest Whitaker]] * [[Oprah Winfrey]] * [[Mariah Carey]] * [[John Cusack]] * [[Jane Fonda]] * [[Cuba Gooding Jr.]] * [[Terrence Howard]] * [[Lenny Kravitz]] * [[James Marsden]] * [[David Oyelowo]] * [[Vanessa Redgrave]] * [[Alan Rickman]] * [[Liev Schreiber]] * [[Robin Williams]] * [[Clarence Williams III]] }} | music = [[Rodrigo Leão]] | cinematography = [[Andrew Dunn (cinematographer)|Andrew Dunn]] | editing = [[Joe Klotz]] | studio = [[Laura Ziskin|Laura Ziskin Productions]]
Windy Hill Pictures
Follow Through Productions
Salamander Pictures
Pam Williams Productions | distributor = [[The Weinstein Company]] | released = {{Film date|2013|08|16}} | runtime = 132 minutes{{cite web|title=''THE BUTLER'' (12A)|url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/butler-film|work=[[Entertainment Film Distributors]]|publisher=[[British Board of Film Classification]]|date=October 15, 2013|accessdate=October 15, 2013}} | country = United States | language = English | budget = $30 million | gross = $176.6 million{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=butler.htm |title=Lee Daniels' The Butler (2013) |publisher=Box Office Mojo |date= |accessdate=August 25, 2014}} }} '''''The Butler''''' (full title '''''Lee Daniels' The Butler'''''){{cite news|last=Lee|first=Chris|title=MPAA permits Weinstein Co. to use 'Lee Daniels' 'The Butler' title|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2013/jul/20/entertainment/la-et-mn-mpaa-weinstein-lee-daniels-butler-title-20130720|accessdate=September 2, 2013|newspaper=The Los Angeles Times|date=July 20, 2013}}{{cite news|last=McNary|first=Dave|title='Lee Daniels' The Butler' Gets First Posters Following MPAA Ruling|url=https://variety.com/2013/film/news/lee-daniels-the-butler-gets-first-posters-following-mpaa-ruling-1200566874/|accessdate=September 2, 2013|newspaper=Variety|date=July 23, 2013}} is a 2013 American [[Historical film|historical]] [[drama film]] directed and produced by [[Lee Daniels]] and written by [[Danny Strong]].{{cite news |last=Nordyke |first=Kimberly |title='The Butler' Trailer: Oprah Winfrey Plays 'Proud' Wife to Forest Whitaker (Video) |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/race/butler-trailer-oprah-winfrey-plays-518900 |accessdate=May 10, 2013|newspaper=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=May 7, 2013}} It is inspired by Wil Haygood's ''Washington Post'' article "A Butler Well Served by This Election". Loosely based on the real life of [[Eugene Allen]] who worked in the White House for decades, the film stars [[Forest Whitaker]] as Cecil Gaines, an [[African Americans|African-American]] who is a witness of notable political and social events of the 20th century during his 34-year tenure serving as a [[White House]] [[butler]].{{cite news |last=Child |first=Ben |title=The Butler trailer: Oprah Winfrey in the White House |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2013/may/09/the-butler-trailer-forest-whitaker |accessdate=May 10, 2013 |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |location=London |date=May 9, 2013}}{{cite news |last=Roberts |first=Roxanne |title=Trailer for 'The Butler,' based on life of the White House's Eugene Allen |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/reliable-source/wp/2013/05/08/trailer-for-the-butler-based-on-life-of-the-white-houses-eugene-allen/ |accessdate=May 10, 2013 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=May 8, 2013 |author2=Amy Argetsinger}} In addition to Whitaker, the film's [[all-star#Entertainment|all-star cast]] also features [[Oprah Winfrey]], [[John Cusack]], [[Jane Fonda]], [[Alex Pettyfer]], [[Cuba Gooding Jr.]], [[Terrence Howard]], [[Lenny Kravitz]], [[James Marsden]], [[David Oyelowo]], [[Vanessa Redgrave]], [[Alan Rickman]], [[Liev Schreiber]], [[Robin Williams]], [[Minka Kelly]], [[Mariah Carey]], and [[Clarence Williams III]]. It was the last film produced by [[Laura Ziskin]],{{cite web |url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/07/citing-its-1916-silent-film-short-warner-bros-blocking-harvey-weinstein-from-using-the-butler-title-on-lee-daniels-film/ |title=UPDATE: David Boies Charges Extortion As He Returns Fire In 'The Butler' Spat Between Warner Bros And The Weinstein Company Directly |last1=Fleming |first1=Mike, Jr. |date=July 6, 2013 |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |accessdate=July 27, 2013}}{{cite news |last=Rosen |first=Christopher |title='The Butler' Trailer: Lee Daniels' 'Forrest Gump' |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/05/08/the-butler-trailer_n_3237243.html |accessdate=May 10, 2013 |newspaper=[[The Huffington Post]] |date=May 9, 2013}} who died in 2011. The film was theatrically released by [[The Weinstein Company]] on August 16, 2013, to mostly positive reviews from critics,{{cite web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2013/07/20/director-lee-daniels-loses-appeal-over-title-of-new-film-the-butler-3891423/|title=The Butler to be re-titled – but only slightly – following dispute over name|last=Williamson|first=Caroline|date=July 20, 2013|publisher=''[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]''|accessdate=August 6, 2013}}{{cite news|last=Feinberg|first=Scott|title='The Butler' Builds Oscar Credentials With Strong Critical, Commercial Debut (Analysis)|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/race/butler-builds-oscar-credentials-strong-608479|accessdate=August 19, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=August 17, 2013}} grossing over $176 million worldwide against a budget of $30 million.{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=butler.htm|title=Lee Daniels' The Butler (2013) - Box Office Mojo|author=|date=|website=www.boxofficemojo.com|accessdate=March 28, 2018}} ==Plot== In 2009, an elderly Cecil Gaines [[Frame story|recounts]] his life story while waiting at the [[White House]] to meet the newly inaugurated president. In 1926, at the age of seven, Gaines is raised on a [[Plantation complexes in the Southeastern United States|cotton plantation]] in [[Macon, Georgia|Macon]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]]. When the farm's owner [[rape]]s Cecil's mother, Cecil's father confronts him and is killed. Cecil is taken in by the estate's caretaker, who trains Cecil as a house servant. In 1937, at age eighteen, Cecil leaves the plantation. Desperately hungry, he breaks into a hotel pastry shop. The elderly master servant, Maynard, takes pity on Cecil and gives him a job. Cecil learns advanced serving and interpersonal skills from Maynard, who later recommends Cecil for a position in a [[Washington, D.C.]] hotel. While working there, Cecil meets and marries Gloria, and the couple has two sons: Louis and Charlie. In 1957, Cecil is hired by the [[White House]] during [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]]'s administration. White House [[maître d'hôtel]] Freddie Fallows introduces Cecil to head butler Carter Wilson and co-worker James Holloway. Cecil witnesses Eisenhower's reluctance to use troops to enforce school desegregation, then his resolve to uphold the law by [[Little Rock Nine|racially integrating]] [[Little Rock Central High School]] in [[Little Rock, Arkansas|Arkansas]]. Louis, the elder son, becomes a university student at [[Fisk University]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], although Cecil feels that the [[Deep South|South]] is too volatile. Louis joins a student program led by [[Southern Christian Leadership Conference]] (SCLC) activist [[James Lawson (American activist)|James Lawson]], which leads to a [[Nonviolence|nonviolent]] [[sit-in]] at a [[Nashville sit-ins|segregated diner]], where he is arrested. Gloria, who feels that Cecil puts his job ahead of her, descends into [[alcoholism]]. In 1961, after [[John F. Kennedy]]'s inauguration, Louis and [[Freedom Riders|others]] are attacked by members of the [[Ku Klux Klan]] while on a [[Freedom Riders|freedom ride]] to [[Birmingham, Alabama]]. Louis participates in the 1963 [[Birmingham Campaign|Birmingham Children's Crusade]], where dogs and water cannons are used to stop the marchers, one of the movement's actions which inspires Kennedy to deliver [[Civil Rights Address|a national address]] proposing the [[Civil Rights Act of 1964]]. After Kennedy is [[Assassination of John F. Kennedy|assassinated]] his successor, [[Lyndon B. Johnson]], enacts the legislation. As a goodwill gesture, [[Jackie Kennedy]] gives Cecil one of the former president's [[necktie]]s. Louis participates in the 1965 [[Selma to Montgomery marches|Selma Voting Rights Movement]], which inspires Johnson to demand that Congress enact the landmark [[1965 Voting Rights Act|Voting Rights Act of 1965]]. Johnson also gives Cecil a [[tie bar]]. In the late 1960s, after civil rights activist [[Martin Luther King, Jr.]]'s [[Assassination of Martin Luther King, Jr.|assassination]], Louis tells his family that he has joined the [[Black Panthers]]. Cecil orders Louis and his girlfriend to leave his house. Louis is arrested again. Cecil becomes aware of President [[Richard Nixon]]'s plans to suppress the Black Panthers. Charlie confides to Louis that he plans to join the [[Vietnam War|war in Vietnam]]. After enlisting, Charlie is killed and buried at [[Arlington National Cemetery]]. When the Black Panthers resort to violence, Louis leaves the organization and returns to college, earning his [[master's degree]] in [[political science]] and eventually running for a seat in [[United States Congress|Congress]], although Cecil continues to hold resentment against him. Cecil repeatedly confronts his supervisor at the White House over the unequal pay and career advancement provided to the black White House staff. With President [[Ronald Reagan]]'s support, Cecil prevails, his reputation growing to the point that he and his wife are invited by the Reagans to be guests at a state dinner. Cecil becomes uncomfortable with the class divisions in the White House. After witnessing Reagan's refusal to support [[Comprehensive Anti-Apartheid Act|economic sanctions]] against Apartheid [[South Africa]], Cecil resigns. Gloria encourages Cecil to mend his relationship with Louis. Realizing his son's actions are heroic, Cecil joins Louis at a protest against [[Apartheid in South Africa|South African apartheid]]; they are arrested and jailed together. In 2008, Gloria dies shortly before [[Barack Obama]] [[United States presidential election, 2008|is elected]] as the nation's first African-American president. Two months, two weeks and one day later, Cecil prepares to meet the newly [[First inauguration of Barack Obama|inaugurated]] President, wearing the articles he received from Kennedy and Johnson. [[Stephen W. Rochon]] approaches Cecil and tells him the president is ready, preparing to show him the way to the Oval Office. Cecil tells him that he knows the way. ==Cast== * [[Forest Whitaker]] as Cecil Gaines, the film's main character, who dedicates his life to becoming a professional [[domestic worker]]. Michael Rainey, Jr. and [[Aml Ameen]] portray Cecil at ages 8 and 15, respectively. ;Gaines' private life * [[Oprah Winfrey]] as Gloria Gaines, Cecil's wife. * [[David Oyelowo]] as Louis Gaines, the Gaines' elder son. * [[Elijah Kelley]] as Charlie Gaines, the Gaines' younger son. Isaac White portrays him at age 10. * [[Alex Pettyfer]] as Thomas Westfall, the brutal plantation owner who kills Earl after raping Cecil's mother. * [[David Banner]] as Earl Gaines,{{cite news|last=Scott|first=A.O.|title=Black Man, White House, and History|url=https://movies.nytimes.com/2013/08/16/movies/lee-daniels-the-butler-stars-forest-whitaker.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|accessdate=August 17, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=August 15, 2013}} Cecil's father. * [[Mariah Carey]] as Hattie Pearl,{{cite web | title=Lee Daniels' The Butler (2013) | url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/456871/Lee-Daniels-The-Butler/cast | publisher = [[All Media Guide]] via ''[[The New York Times]]'' | accessdate=August 8, 2013}} Cecil's mother. * [[Terrence Howard]] as Howard, the Gaines' neighbor who romantically pursues Gloria. * [[Adriane Lenox]] as Gina. Howard's wife. * [[Yaya DaCosta]] as Carol Hammie, Louis' girlfriend.{{cite web|last=Johnson|first=Terence|title=Awards Profile: The Butler|url=http://www.awardscircuit.com/2013/04/12/awards-profile-the-butler/|publisher=Awards Circuit|accessdate=May 12, 2013}} * [[Vanessa Redgrave]] as Annabeth Westfall, matron of the plantation. * [[Clarence Williams III]] as Maynard, an elderly man who mentors a young Cecil and introduces him to his profession. ;White House co-workers * [[Cuba Gooding Jr.]] as Carter Wilson, the fast-talking head butler at the White House, with whom Cecil forms a close friendship. * [[Lenny Kravitz]] as James Holloway, a co-worker butler of Cecil's at the White House. * [[Colman Domingo]] as Freddie Fallows, the White House maitre d' who hires Cecil. ;White House historical figures * [[Robin Williams]] as [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]],{{cite news |last=Labrecque |first=Jeff |title='The Butler': The new trailer showcases Oscar-winning actors tackling history – VIDEO |url=http://popwatch.ew.com/2013/05/08/the-butler-trailer-presidents/ |accessdate=May 10, 2013 |publisher=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |work=PopWatch (column)|date=May 8, 2013}} the 34th [[President of the United States]]. * James DuMont as [[Sherman Adams]], Eisenhower's [[White House Chief of Staff]].{{cite web|last=Ingram|first=Bruce|title=Fame comes second for Evanston actor starring in 'The Butler'|url=http://lincolnshire.suntimes.com/people/butler-DIN-08152013:article|publisher=Sun-Times Media|accessdate=August 17, 2013|date=August 16, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131016213249/http://lincolnshire.suntimes.com/people/butler-DIN-08152013:article|archivedate=October 16, 2013|df=mdy-all}} * Robert Aberdeen as [[Herbert Brownell Jr.]], Eisenhower's [[Attorney General]].{{cite news|title=Lee Daniels' The Butler (2013)|url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/456871/Lee-Daniels-The-Butler/cast|accessdate=August 17, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times}} * [[James Marsden]] as [[John F. Kennedy]], the 35th President of the United States. * [[Minka Kelly]] as [[First Lady of the United States|First Lady]] [[Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis|Jackie Kennedy]] * [[Liev Schreiber]] as [[Lyndon B. Johnson]], the 36th President of the United States. * [[John Cusack]] as [[Richard Nixon]], the 37th President of the United States. * Alex Manette as [[H. R. Haldeman]], Nixon's [[White House Chief of Staff]]. * Colin Walker as [[John Ehrlichman]], Nixon's [[White House Counsel]].{{cite news|last=Wirt|first=John|title=N.O. native Walker joins The Butler cast|url=http://theadvocate.com/utility/homepagestories/6781003-129/no-native-walker-joins-the|accessdate=August 17, 2013|newspaper=The Advocate|date=August 16, 2013}} * [[Alan Rickman]] as [[Ronald Reagan]], the 40th President of the United States. * [[Jane Fonda]] as First Lady [[Nancy Reagan]] * [[Stephen Rider]] as [[Stephen W. Rochon]], [[Barack Obama]]'s [[White House Chief Usher]]. ;Civil rights historical figures * [[Nelsan Ellis]] as [[Martin Luther King, Jr.]]. * [[Jesse Williams (actor)|Jesse Williams]] as civil rights activist [[James Lawson (American activist)|James Lawson]] * [[Danny Strong]], the film's screenwriter, appears as a [[Freedom Riders|Freedom Bus]] journalist. Presidents [[Gerald Ford]], [[Jimmy Carter]], [[Barack Obama]] and civil rights leader [[Jesse Jackson]] are depicted in [[Archive footage|archival footage]].{{cite news|last=Makarechi|first=Kia|title='Lee Daniels' The Butler' Celebrated By Oprah, Forest Whitaker, Gayle King & More In New York|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/08/01/lee-daniels-the-butler-screening_n_3685944.html|accessdate=August 19, 2013|publisher=The Huffington Post|date=August 1, 2013}} [[Melissa Leo]] and Orlando Eric Street were cast as First Lady [[Mamie Eisenhower]] and Barack Obama, respectively, but did not appear in the finished film.{{cite news|last=Williams|first=Kam|title=Two-time Oscar-nominee talks about his latest film Lee Daniels' 'The Butler'|url=http://baystatebanner.com/news/2013/aug/15/two-time-oscar-nominee-talks-about-his-latest-film/|accessdate=August 19, 2013|newspaper=The Bay State Banner|date=August 15, 2013}}{{cite news|last=Child|first=Ben|title=Lee Daniels pleads with Warner Bros to retain title of The Butler|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2013/jul/04/lee-daniels-warner-brothers-the-butler|accessdate=August 19, 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=July 4, 2013}}{{cite news|title='The Butler' Poster: Lee Daniels' New Film Fits Massive Cast List On New One-Sheet|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/06/03/the-butler-poster_n_3366504.html|accessdate=August 19, 2013|newspaper=The Huffington Post|date=June 3, 2013}} ==Production== ===Development=== [[Danny Strong]]'s screenplay is inspired by Wil Haygood's ''[[The Washington Post|Washington Post]]'' article "A Butler Well Served by This Election".{{cite news |last=Haygood |first=Wil |title=A Butler Well Served by This Election|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/11/06/AR2008110603948_pf.html |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=November 7, 2008}}{{cite web |author=The Reliable Source | date= August 6, 2013 | title= No, President Obama isn't doing a cameo in 'The Butler' | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/reliable-source/wp/2013/08/06/no-president-obama-isnt-doing-a-cameo-in-the-butler/ |department=Reliable Source (blog) | work=[[The Washington Post]] | accessdate=August 8, 2013}} The project received initial backing in early 2011, when producers Laura Ziskin and Pam Williams approached [[Sheila Johnson]] for help in financing the film. After reading Danny Strong's screenplay, Johnson pitched in her own $2.7 million before bringing in several African-American investors. However, Ziskin died from cancer in June 2011. This left director Daniels and producing partner Hilary Shor to look for further producers on their own. They started with [[Cassian Elwes]], with whom they were working on [[The Paperboy (2012 film)|''The Paperboy'']]. Elwes joined the list of producers, and started raising funding for the film. In spring 2012, Icon U.K., a British financing and production company, added a $6 million guarantee against foreign pre-sales. Finally the film raised its needed $30 million budget through 41 producers and executive producers, including Earl W. Stafford, Harry I. Martin Jr., Brett Johnson, [[Michael Finley]], and Buddy Patrick. Thereafter, as film production started [[Weinstein Co.]] picked up U.S. distribution rights for the film. David Glasser, Weinstein Co. COO, called fund raising as an independent film, "a story that's a movie within itself."{{cite web| title = Why 'Lee Daniels' The Butler' Has 41 Producers| url = http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/why-lee-daniels-butler-has-605011|date=August 14, 2013| accessdate = August 15, 2013|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]}}{{cite web| title = Lee Daniels' The Butler: The film with FORTY ONE producers: How a host of stars and entrepreneurs raised $30m to fund The Butler |work=[[Daily Mail]] | url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2394397/Lee-Daniels-The-Butler--The-film-FORTY-ONE-producers-How-host-stars-entrepreneurs-raised-30m-fund-The-Butler.html |date=August 15, 2013| accessdate = August 15, 2013}} [[The Weinstein Company]] acquired the distribution rights for the film after [[Columbia Pictures]] put the film in [[Turnaround (filmmaking)|turnaround]].{{cite web |last=Brevet |first=Brad |title=New Look at 'The Butler' as the Weinstein Co. Picks It Up for Distribution |url=http://www.ropeofsilicon.com/weinstein-co-butler-distribution-whitaker-daniels/ |publisher=Ropes of Silicon |accessdate=May 10, 2013 |date=September 24, 2012}}{{cite news |last=Kit |first=Borys |title=Columbia tells White House butler story |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/columbia-tells-white-house-butler-123281 |accessdate=May 10, 2013 |newspaper=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=November 19, 2008}} The film's title was up for a possible rename due to a [[Motion Picture Association of America]] claim from [[Warner Bros.]], which had inherited from the defunct Lubin Company a now-lost 1916 silent short film with the same name.{{cite news |last=Johnson |first=Ted |title=Harvey Weinstein Has Already Won 'The Butler' Battle (Opinion) |url=https://variety.com/2013/biz/biz/the-butler-title-tiff-why-weinstein-is-already-victorious-1200560460/ |accessdate=July 10, 2013 |newspaper=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=July 9, 2013}} The case was subsequently resolved with the MPAA granting The Weinstein Company permission to add Daniels' name in front of the title, under the condition that his name was "75% the size of ''The Butler''{{-"}}.{{cite web |url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/07/toldja-mpaa-oks-weinstein-co-to-use-lee-daniels-the-butler/ |title=TOLDJA! Weinstein Co. Can Title Its Movie 'Lee Daniels' The Butler', If It Wants |date=July 19, 2013 |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |accessdate=July 23, 2013}} On July 23, 2013, the distributor unveiled a revised poster, displaying the title as ''Lee Daniels' The Butler''.{{cite web |url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/07/weinstein-co-unveils-new-poster-for-lee-daniels-the-butler-to-comply-with-mpaa/ |title=Weinstein Co Unveils New Poster For 'Lee Daniels' The Butler' To Comply With MPAA |author=The Deadline Team |date=July 23, 2013 |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |accessdate=July 23, 2013}} ===Filming=== [[Principal photography]] started in June 2012 in [[New Orleans]]. Production was originally scheduled to wrap in early August 2012 but was delayed by the impact of [[Hurricane Isaac (2012)|Hurricane Isaac]].{{cite news|last=Scott|first=Mike|title=Tropical Storm Isaac chases 'The Butler' away, as film suspends production|url=http://www.nola.com/movies/index.ssf/2012/08/tropical_storm_isaac_chases_th.html|newspaper=The Times-Picayune|date=August 27, 2012}} ==Reception== === Box office performance === In its opening weekend, the film debuted in first place with $24.6 million.{{cite news|last=Kilday|first=Gregg|title=Box Office Report: 'The Butler' Tops the Field With $25 Million|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/box-office-report-butler-tops-608689|accessdate=August 19, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=August 18, 2013}}{{cite news|last=Mendelson|first=Scott|title=Weekend Box Office: 'The Butler' Opens To $25m, 'Kick-Ass 2', 'Jobs', And 'Paranoia' Crash|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2013/08/18/weekend-box-office-the-butler-opens-to-25m-kick-ass-2-jobs-paranoia-crash/|accessdate=August 19, 2013|newspaper=Forbes|date=August 18, 2013}} The film topped the North American box office in its first three consecutive weeks.{{cite news|last=Cunningham|first=Todd|title=Oprah Winfrey's 'The Butler' Powers Past 'One Direction' for 3rd Straight Box-Office Win|url=http://mc-3596-1705542522.us-west-2.elb.amazonaws.com/movies/article/oprah-winfrey-s-butler-powers-past-one-direction-3rd-straight-box-office-win-114621|accessdate=September 2, 2013|newspaper=The Wrap|date=September 2, 2013}}{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}{{cite news|last=McClintock|first=Pamela|title=Box Office Report: 'The Butler' Wins Again With $17 Million, Crosses $50 Million|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/box-office-report-butler-wins-614083|accessdate=August 26, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=August 25, 2013}} The film has grossed $116.6 million in Canada and the United States, it earned $51.1 million elsewhere, for a total of $167.7 million. ===Critical response=== ''The Butler'' received mostly positive reviews from critics, with a 71% rating on the [[film critic]] aggregate site [[Rotten Tomatoes]], based on 175 reviews. The site's consensus says, "Gut-wrenching and emotionally affecting, ''Lee Daniels' The Butler'' overcomes an uneven narrative thanks to strong performances from an all-star cast."{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/lee_daniels_the_butler/ |title=''Lee Daniels' The Butler'' (2013) |publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |date=August 16, 2013 |accessdate=August 16, 2013}} Another review aggregator, [[Metacritic]], which assigns a [[Normalization (statistics)|normalized]] rating out of 100 top reviews from mainstream critics, calculated a score of 66 based on 47 reviews, indicating "generally positive reviews".{{cite web|title=Lee Daniels' The Butler|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/lee-daniels-the-butler|publisher=Metacritic|accessdate=August 16, 2013}} [[Todd McCarthy]] praised the film saying, "Even with all contrivances and obvious point-making and familiar historical signposting, Daniels' ''The Butler'' is always engaging, often entertaining and certainly never dull."{{cite news|last=McCarthy|first=Todd|title=Lee Daniels' The Butler: Film Review|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/movie/butler/review/601991|accessdate=August 16, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=August 9, 2013}} [[Richard Roeper]] lauded the film's casting in particular, remarking that "Forest Whitaker gives the performance of his career".{{cite news|last=Roeper|first=Richard|title=Lee Daniels' The Butler|url=http://www.richardroeper.com/reviews/leedanielsthebutler.aspx|accessdate=August 16, 2013|newspaper=Richard Roeper & The Movies}} [[Rolling Stone (magazine)|''Rolling Stone'']] also spoke highly of Whitaker writing that his "reflective, powerfully understated performance...fills this flawed film with potency and purpose."{{cite news|last=Travers|first=Peter|title=Lee Daniels' The Butler|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/reviews/lee-daniels-the-butler-20130815|accessdate=August 16, 2013|newspaper=Rolling Stone|date=August 15, 2013}} [[Variety (magazine)|''Variety'']] wrote that "Daniels develops a strong sense of the inner complexities and contradictions of the civil-rights landscape."{{cite news|last=Foundas|first=Scott|title=Film Review: 'Lee Daniels' The Butler'|url=https://variety.com/2013/film/reviews/lee-daniels-the-butler-review-forest-whitaker-oprah-winfrey-1200575215/|accessdate=August 16, 2013|newspaper=Variety|date=August 8, 2013}} ''[[USA Today]]'' gave the film three out of four stars and noted that "It's inspiring and filled with fine performances, but the insistently swelling musical score and melodramatic moments seem calculated and undercut a powerful story."{{cite news|last=Puig|first=Claudia|title='The Butler' is mannered and moving|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/movies/2013/08/15/the-butler-review/2581949/|accessdate=August 16, 2013|newspaper=USA Today|date=August 15, 2013}} Miles Davis of the ''[[New York Tribune]]'' gave the film a negative review, claiming the film to be "[[Oscar bait]]", a cliche film designed to attract Oscar nominations."The Butler Review", New York Tribune, 2013. [[Kenneth Turan]] of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' was more negative; "An ambitious and overdue attempt to create a Hollywood-style epic around the experience of black Americans in general and the civil rights movement in particular, it undercuts itself by hitting its points squarely on the nose with a 9-pound hammer."{{cite news|last=Turan|first=Kenneth|title=Review: 'Lee Daniels' The Butler' significant but often contrived|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/moviesnow/la-et-mn-review-the-butler,0,581076.story|accessdate=August 16, 2013|newspaper=The Los Angeles Times|date=August 15, 2013}} Several critics compared the film's historical anecdotes and sentimentality to [[Forrest Gump (film)|''Forrest Gump'']].{{cite news|last=Anderson|first=John|title='Lee Daniels' The Butler' movie review|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/goingoutguide/movies/lee-daniels-the-butler-movie-review/2013/08/14/a8976a42-0443-11e3-9259-e2aafe5a5f84_story.html|accessdate=August 16, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=August 15, 2013}}{{cite news|last=Rodriguez|first=Rene|title='Lee Daniels' The Butler' (PG-13)|url=http://www.miami.com/039lee-daniels039-butler039-pg-13-article|accessdate=August 16, 2013|newspaper=Miami Herald|date=August 15, 2013}}{{cite news|last=Williams|first=Joe|title=Forest Whitaker shines as 'The Butler'|url=http://www.stltoday.com/entertainment/movies/reviews/forest-whitaker-shines-as-the-butler/article_9622adf4-b80a-584c-b0ec-6dcb97a840b2.html|accessdate=August 16, 2013|newspaper=St. Louis Post-Dispatch|date=August 15, 2013}}{{cite news|last=Burr|first=Ty|title='The Butler' examines civil rights history from a new perspective|url=http://www.boston.com/ae/movies/2013/08/15/movie-review-lee-daniels-the-butler-examines-civil-rights-history-from-whole-new-perspective/XRwirtvqC0IWlFk0o1Mj0M/story.html|accessdate=August 16, 2013|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=August 15, 2013}} President [[Barack Obama]] said, "I teared up thinking about not just the butlers who worked here in the White House, but an entire generation of people who were talented and skilled. But because of [[Jim Crow laws|Jim Crow]] and because of [[discrimination]], there was only so far they could go."{{cite news|last=Child|first=Ben |title=Barack Obama 'teared up' watching Oscar-tipped drama The Butler |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2013/aug/28/barack-obama-oscar-tipped-drama-butler |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=August 28, 2013}} === Accolades === {| class="wikitable" width="100%" |- style="background:#ccc; text-align:center;" ! colspan="5" style="background: LightSteelBlue;" | Awards |- style="background:#ccc; text-align:center;" ! Award ! Category ! Recipients and nominees ! Result |- |[[AARP The Magazine|AARP Annual Movies for Grownups Awards]]{{cite news|title=AARP Names '12 Years a Slave' Best Movie for Grownups|url=https://variety.com/2014/film/news/12-years-a-slave-best-movie-1201032352/|accessdate=January 6, 2014|newspaper=AFI|date=January 6, 2014}} | Best Supporting Actress | Oprah Winfrey | {{won}} |- |rowspan=2|[[British Academy Film Awards|BAFTA Awards]] |[[BAFTA Award for Best Actress in a Supporting Role|Best Actress in a Supporting Role]] |Oprah Winfrey |{{nom}} |- |[[BAFTA Award for Best Makeup and Hair]] |Debra Denson, Beverly Jo Pryor, Candace Neal |{{nom}} |- |rowspan=2|[[Hollywood Film Festival|Hollywood Film Awards]] |Best Director |Lee Daniels |{{won}} |- |Spotlight |[[David Oyelowo]] |{{won}} |- |rowspan=3|[[Critics Choice Awards]] |[[Broadcast Film Critics Association Award for Best Supporting Actress|Best Supporting Actress]] |[[Oprah Winfrey]] |{{nom}} |- |[[Broadcast Film Critics Association Award for Best Cast|Best Cast]] |[[Mariah Carey]], [[John Cusack]], [[Jane Fonda]], [[Cuba Gooding Jr.]], [[Terrence Howard]], [[Lenny Kravitz]], [[James Marsden]], David Oyelowo, [[Alex Pettyfer]], [[Vanessa Redgrave]], [[Alan Rickman]], [[Liev Schreiber]], [[Forest Whitaker]], [[Robin Williams]], and Oprah Winfrey |{{nom}} |- |[[Broadcast Film Critics Association Award for Best Makeup|Best Makeup]] | |{{nom}} |- |rowspan=8|[[NAACP Image Award]]{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/naacp-image-awards-winners-682585|title=NAACP Image Awards: The Winners|author=Aaron Couch, Arlene Washington|date=February 22, 2014|accessdate=February 22, 2014|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]}} |[[45th NAACP Image Awards#Outstanding Motion Picture|Outstanding Motion Picture]] | |{{nom}} |- |[[45th NAACP Image Awards#Outstanding Actor in a Motion Picture|Outstanding Actor in a Motion Picture]] |[[Forest Whitaker]] |{{won}} |- |[[45th NAACP Image Awards#Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Motion Picture|Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Motion Picture]] |[[David Oyelowo]] |{{won}} |- |[[45th NAACP Image Awards#Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Motion Picture|Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Motion Picture]] |[[Cuba Gooding Jr.]] |{{nom}} |- |[[45th NAACP Image Awards#Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Motion Picture|Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Motion Picture]] |[[Terrence Howard]] |{{nom}} |- |[[45th NAACP Image Awards#Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Motion Picture|Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Motion Picture]] |[[Oprah Winfrey]] |{{nom}} |- |[[45th NAACP Image Awards#Outstanding Writing in a Motion Picture - (Theatrical or Television)|Outstanding Writing in a Motion Picture]] |[[Danny Strong]] |{{nom}} |- |[[45th NAACP Image Awards#Outstanding Directing in a Motion Picture - (Theatrical or Television)|Outstanding Directing in a Motion Picture]] |[[Lee Daniels]] |{{nom}} |- |rowspan=2|[[People's Choice Awards]] |Favorite Dramatic Movie | |{{nom}} |- |Favorite Dramatic Movie Actress |Oprah Winfrey |{{nom}} |- |Phoenix Film Critics Society |Best Actress in a Supporting Role |Oprah Winfrey |{{nom}} |- |rowspan=3|[[Screen Actors Guild Award]] |[[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Cast in a Motion Picture|Outstanding Performance by a Cast in a Motion Picture]] |Mariah Carey, John Cusack, Jane Fonda, Cuba Gooding Jr., Terrence Howard, Lenny Kravitz, James Marsden, David Oyelowo, Alex Pettyfer, Vanessa Redgrave, Alan Rickman, Liev Schreiber, Forest Whitaker, Robin Williams, and Oprah Winfrey |{{nom}} |- |[[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Male Actor in a Leading Role|Outstanding Performance by a Male Actor in a Leading Role]] |Forest Whitaker |{{nom}} |- |[[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Female Actor in a Supporting Role|Outstanding Performance by a Female Actor in a Supporting Role]] |Oprah Winfrey |{{nom}} |- |rowspan=3|[[Satellite Awards]] |Best Actor in a Motion Picture |Forest Whitaker |{{nom}} |- |Best Actress in Supporting Role |Oprah Winfrey |{{nom}} |- |Best Art Direction & Production Design |Diane Lederman, Tim Galvin |{{nom}} |} ===Historical accuracy=== Regarding historical accuracy, Eliana Dockterman wrote in ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'': "Allen was born on a [[Virginia]] plantation in 1919, not in Georgia.... In the movie, Cecil Gaines grows up on a cotton field in Macon, where his family comes into conflict with the white farmers for whom they work. What befalls his parents on the cotton field was [[Stereotypes of African Americans|added for dramatic effect]].... Though tension between father and son over civil rights issues fuels most of the drama in the film, [Eugene Allen's son] Charles Allen was not the radical political activist that Gaines's son is in the movie."{{cite news|last=Dockterman |first=Eliana |title=The True Story of The Butler: Fact vs. Fiction in Lee Daniels' The Butler |url=http://entertainment.time.com/2013/08/16/what-the-butler-really-saw/ |newspaper=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=August 16, 2013}} Particular criticism has been directed at the film's accuracy in portraying President [[Ronald Reagan]]. While Alan Rickman's performance generated positive reviews, the director and screenwriters of the film have been criticized for depicting Reagan as indifferent to civil rights and his reluctance to associate with the White House's black employees during his presidency. According to [[Michael Reagan]], the former president's son, "The real story of the White House butler doesn't imply racism at all. It's simply Hollywood liberals wanting to believe something about my father that was never there."{{cite news|last=Bond|first=Paul|title=President Reagan's Son Attacks 'Lee Daniels' The Butler'|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/president-reagans-son-attacks-lee-614568 |accessdate=August 28, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=August 26, 2013}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2013/aug/29/the-butler-ronald-reagan-not-racist|publisher=The Guardian|title=The Butler falsely portrays Ronald Reagan as racist, says son|date=August 29, 2013|accessdate=September 1, 2013}}{{cite news|publisher=Newsmax|title=The Butler from Another Planet|url=http://www.newsmax.com/Reagan/Butler-Reagan-Oprah-Allen/2013/08/22/id/521814|date=August 27, 2013|first=Michael|last=Reagan|accessdate=December 25, 2013}} [[Paul Kengor]], one of President Reagan's biographers, also attacked the film, saying, "I've talked to many White House staff, cooks, housekeepers, doctors, and Secret Service over the years. They are universal in their love of Ronald Reagan." In regard to the president's initial opposition to sanctions against [[apartheid]] in South Africa, Kengor said, "Ronald Reagan was appalled by apartheid, but also wanted to ensure that if the apartheid regime collapsed in South Africa that it wasn't replaced by a Marxist-totalitarian regime allied with Moscow and Cuba that would take the South African people down the same road as Ethiopia, Mozambique, and, yes, Cuba. In the immediate years before Reagan became president, 11 countries from the Third World, from Asia to Africa to Latin America, went Communist. It was devastating. If the film refuses to deal with this issue with the necessary balance, it shouldn't deal with it at all."{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/lee-daniels-butler-reagan-biographers-608233|title=Lee Daniels' 'The Butler': Reagan Biographers Slam President's Portrayal|work=The Hollywood Reporter.com|date=August 16, 2013|accessdate=September 1, 2013}} ==See also== * ''[[Backstairs at the White House]]'', a 1979 miniseries with a similar theme * [[African-American Civil Rights Movement (1954–68) in popular culture]] * [[Great Migration (African American)|Great Migration]] * [[List of black films of the 2010s]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.weinsteinco.com/sites/leedanielsthebutler/ Official website] * {{IMDb title|1327773|The Butler}} * {{mojo title|butler|The Butler}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|lee_daniels_the_butler|The Butler}} * {{metacritic film|lee-daniels-the-butler|The Butler}} {{Lee Daniels|state=expanded}} {{Danny Strong}} {{African-American Civil Rights Movement}} {{Portal bar|2010s|African Americans|Film in the United States|Government of the United States}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Butler}} [[Category:2013 films]] [[Category:2010s drama films]] [[Category:2010s historical films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American drama films]] [[Category:American historical films]] [[Category:American political drama films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films directed by Lee Daniels]] [[Category:African-American films]] [[Category:African-American civil rights movement (1954–68) in film]] [[Category:Films about politicians]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Dwight D. Eisenhower]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Martin Luther King Jr.]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of John F. Kennedy]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Lyndon B. Johnson]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Richard Nixon]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Gerald Ford]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Jimmy Carter]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Ronald Reagan]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Barack Obama]] [[Category:Films about Presidents of the United States]] [[Category:Films about race and ethnicity]] [[Category:Films about racism]] [[Category:Films based on actual events]] [[Category:Films based on newspaper and magazine articles]] [[Category:Films based on biographies]] [[Category:Films set in 1926]] [[Category:Films set in 1937]] [[Category:Films set in 1957]] [[Category:Films set in 1960]] [[Category:Films set in 1961]] [[Category:Films set in 1963]] [[Category:Films set in 1964]] [[Category:Films set in 1965]] [[Category:Films set in 1968]] [[Category:Films set in 1969]] [[Category:Films set in 1973]] [[Category:Films set in 1974]] [[Category:Films set in 1986]] [[Category:Films set in 2008]] [[Category:Films set in 2009]] [[Category:Films set in Alabama]] [[Category:Films set in Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:Films set in Tennessee]] [[Category:Films set in Oakland, California]] [[Category:Films set in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Films shot in New Orleans]] [[Category:United States presidential election, 2008 in popular culture]] [[Category:United States presidential succession in fiction]] [[Category:Alliance Films films]] [[Category:Screenplays by Danny Strong]] [[Category:Films set in the White House]] [[Category:Films about rape]]

page.title: The Execution of Lady Jane Grey

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox Artwork |image_file = PAUL DELAROCHE - Ejecución de Lady Jane Grey (National Gallery de Londres, 1834).jpg |image_size = 330px |title = The Execution of Lady Jane Grey |other_language_1 = |other_title_1 = |other_language_2 = |other_title_2 = |artist = [[Paul Delaroche]] |year = 1833 |medium = [[Oil on canvas]] |height_metric =246 |width_metric = 297 |height_imperial = |width_imperial = |metric_unit=cm |imperial_unit=in |city = London |museum = [[National Gallery, London|National Gallery]] }} '''''The Execution of Lady Jane Grey''''' is an oil painting by [[Paul Delaroche]], completed in 1833, which is now in the [[National Gallery (London)|National Gallery]] in London (in 2018 on loan to an exhibition in Houston). It was enormously popular in the decades after it was painted, but in the 20th century realist historical paintings fell from critical favour and it was kept in storage for many decades, for much of which it was thought lost. Restored and displayed again since 1975, it immediately once again became a highly popular work, especially with younger visitors.<ref>Adams, Tim, [http://www.newstatesman.com/art/2010/03/delaroche-painting-tudor-jane "How Tudorphilia rescued Delaroche"], in ''[[New Statesman]]''</ref>
The painting portrays, erroneously in some regards, the moments preceding the death of [[Lady Jane Grey]], who on 10 July 1553 was proclaimed [[Monarch of England|Queen of England]], only to be deposed nine days later and executed in 1554. Jane is sometimes referred to as the "Nine Days' Queen" due to the brevity of her reign.<ref>{{citeweb|url=http://www.hrp.org.uk/Resources/Lady%20Jane%20Grey.pdf|format=PDF|title=Factsheet: Lady Jane Grey, Nine Days Queen|publisher=''Tower of London''. Historic Royal Palaces|accessdate=4 September 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080910122313/http://www.hrp.org.uk/Resources/Lady%20Jane%20Grey.pdf|archivedate=10 September 2008|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Subject== {{main|Lady Jane Grey}} Lady Jane Grey was the great-granddaughter of [[Henry VII of England]] and first cousin once removed to his grandson, the short-lived [[Edward VI of England|Edward VI]]. After Edward's death she was proclaimed queen, being given precedence over [[Henry VIII]]'s daughters, [[Mary I of England|Mary Tudor]] and [[Elizabeth I of England|Elizabeth]]. Two weeks after the death of her brother, Mary, who had the support of the English people, claimed the throne, which Jane relinquished, having reigned for only nine days. Jane, her husband [[Lord Guilford Dudley]], and her father, were imprisoned in the [[Tower of London]] on charges of [[high treason]]. Jane's trial was conducted in November, but the death penalty handed to her was temporarily suspended. In February 1554, Jane's father, who had been released, was one of the rebel leaders in [[Wyatt's rebellion]]. On Friday 12 February, Mary had Jane, then aged 16, and her husband [[behead]]ed. Her father followed two days later.<ref>{{citeweb|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/historic_figures/grey_lady_jane.shtml|title=Historic Figures – Lady Jane Grey (1537–1554)|publisher=[[BBC]]|accessdate=7 September 2008}}</ref>
==Treatment==
Delaroche painted the subject of Lady Jane's execution in 1833, nearly 300 years after the event, drawing upon contemporary historical sources to help him portray it accurately. Delaroche had built his reputation in the Paris salon with large, realistic portrayals of famous events from the previous few centuries.<ref name=4learning>{{citeweb|url=http://www.channel4.com/learning/main/netnotes/sectionid100663638.htm|title=National Gallery, Programme 5|publisher=[[Channel 4]]|author=Ghislaine Kenyon|accessdate=4 September 2008}}</ref> Despite the artist's familiarity with the painting of historical narratives, there are aspects of the painting which are inaccurate.
[[File:Delaroche Jane Grey Detail.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.0|Detail]] The painting depicts the moment that Jane, blindfolded, is being assisted to lay her head upon the block for the executioner. Her outstretched hand reaches uncertainly down to find the block. She is being assisted by a man who is identified as [[John Brydges, 1st Baron Chandos]]. Chandos was a Lieutenant of the Tower at the time of Jane's execution.<ref name=NatGal>{{citeweb| title =The Execution of Lady Jane Grey| publisher =[[National Gallery, London]]| url =http://www.nationalgallery.org.uk/cgi-bin/WebObjects.dll/CollectionPublisher.woa/wa/work?workNumber=ng1909| accessdate =7 September 2008| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20090507120243/http://www.nationalgallery.org.uk/cgi-bin/WebObjects.dll/CollectionPublisher.woa/wa/work?workNumber=ng1909| archivedate =7 May 2009| df =dmy-all}}</ref> While imprisoned in the Tower, Jane was attended by [[Lady-in-waiting|ladies in waiting]], one of whom was the [[nursemaid]] of her infancy.
